result.markdown:
--- title: "Quantifying Transportation's Economic Ripple Effects" subtitle: "Methods and Applications for Regional Planning" author: "Pukar Bhandari" date: "August 2025" format: revealjs: slide-number: true show-slide-number: all incremental: true transition: slide background-transition: fade highlight-style: ayu-mirage mainfont: "Atkinson Hyperlegible" fontsize: "24px" chalkboard: true preview-links: auto logo: "" footer: "Transportation Data Scientist Candidate | WFRC Interview" css: custom-style.css execute: eval: false warning: false message: false --- ## Professional Background {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="70%"} **Experience:** - Graduate education at University of Utah (Salt Lake City) - 3+ years in travel demand modeling & economic impact analysis - Led economic assessments for Utah's $30+ billion Unified Transportation Plan **Technical Expertise:** - Travel demand modeling: Cube, TransCAD - Economic modeling: IMPLAN, TREDIS - Data science: R, Python, spatial analysis - Specialization: Quantifying transportation's economic ripple effects ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: info-box **Today's Focus:** Economic impact analysis for WFRC
  • Investment prioritization
  • 2034 Olympic planning
  • Regional growth management
  • Stakeholder communications
*Drawing from Utah UTP experience and multi-state MPO projects* ::: ::: :::: ::: {.notes} - Brief personal intro: 3+ years experience in travel demand modeling and economic impact analysis - Excited to discuss how these methods can support WFRC's regional planning mission - Draw from experience with Utah UTP 2023-2050 and multiple MPO projects ::: --- ## The Challenge: Beyond Mobility {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} **Traditional transportation analysis focuses on:** - Travel time savings - Vehicle miles traveled - Traffic flow improvements **But decision-makers need to understand:** - Job creation and economic growth - Regional competitiveness impacts - Return on infrastructure investment - Distributional effects across communities ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ![Economic Impact Conceptual Framework](placeholder-economic-framework.png) *Direct → Indirect → Induced Effects* ::: :::: ::: {.fragment} **Especially critical for WFRC**: Fastest-growing region, 2034 Olympics, electrification planning ::: ::: {.notes} - Set up the problem: MPOs need to justify investments beyond just traffic metrics - WFRC faces unique challenges with rapid growth and upcoming Olympics - Economic analysis helps prioritize limited resources ::: --- ## Methodological Framework {.smaller} ```{mermaid} flowchart TD A[Travel Demand ModelsCube/TransCAD] --> B[Trip Pattern AnalysisR/Python] C[Socioeconomic DataCensus/ACS/LEHD] --> B D[Employment DataLODES/BLS] --> B B --> E[Economic Impact ModelsIMPLAN/TREDIS] E --> F[Regional Economic EffectsJobs, Income, GDP] G[Automated R Workflows] --> B G --> E style A fill:#e1f5fe style E fill:#f3e5f5 style F fill:#e8f5e8 style G fill:#fff3e0 ``` ::: {.fragment} **Key Innovation**: Automated, reproducible workflows using R for data integration and analysis ::: ::: {.notes} - Show how I integrate transportation modeling with economic analysis - Emphasize the R-based automation - aligns with WFRC's need for maintainable processes - This is where my technical skills differentiate me from other candidates ::: --- ## Real Application: Utah UTP 2023-2050 {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} **Project Scope:** - Utah's $30+ billion transportation plan - Multi-modal investment scenarios - Regional travel demand integration - Real-estate market model coupling **Key Findings:** - Construction phase: 15,000+ direct jobs - Operations phase: $2.8B annual economic impact - Induced effects across 6-county region - Significant accessibility improvements in underserved areas ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: **Economic Impact by Sector** *[Visualization showing construction, manufacturing, services impacts]* ::: :::: ::: {.fragment} **Methodology**: Integrated Cube travel demand outputs with IMPLAN economic multipliers using custom R scripts ::: ::: {.notes} - This is my "wow" slide - show concrete results from Utah work - Demonstrates both technical capability and local knowledge - Numbers are impressive and relevant to WFRC's scale of planning - Mention the R integration as key technical contribution ::: --- ## Value Proposition for WFRC {.smaller} **Immediate Applications:** ::: {.incremental} - **Investment Prioritization**: Compare economic returns across RTP projects - **2034 Olympics Planning**: Quantify long-term economic legacy of transportation investments - **Electrification Strategy**: Model economic co-benefits of transit electrification - **Equity Analysis**: Identify which communities benefit most from transportation investments - **Stakeholder Communication**: Translate complex analyses into compelling narratives for elected officials ::: . . . **Technical Advantages:** - Reproducible R-based workflows align with WFRC's analytical standards - Integration with existing travel demand modeling processes - Scalable from corridor-level to regional analysis ::: {.notes} - Connect directly to WFRC's current priorities and challenges - Show how this isn't just academic - it's immediately useful - Emphasize the R integration since that matches their technical environment - Olympics connection is unique value I bring given my Utah experience ::: --- ## Discussion & Next Steps {.center} ### Questions I'd love to explore with the WFRC team: ::: {.incremental} - What are your current approaches to economic analysis for the RTP? - How do you currently communicate economic benefits to stakeholders? - What role might this analysis play in Olympic transportation planning? - How can we integrate this with your transition to activity-based modeling? ::: . . . ### **Thank you!** **Pukar Bhandari** pukar.bhandari@outlook.com | github.com/ar-puuk ::: {.notes} - End with questions that show genuine interest in their specific challenges - Demonstrates collaborative mindset - Opens door for technical discussion about their current methods - Activity-based modeling question shows I understand their strategic priorities ::: --- ## Backup Slides {.smaller} ### Technical Details: R Workflow Architecture ```r # Example workflow structure library(tidyverse) library(sf) library(targets) # For reproducible pipelines # 1. Data Integration travel_data <- process_cube_outputs("model_results/") employment_data <- pull_lodes_data(study_area) # 2. Economic Multiplier Application economic_impacts <- calculate_impacts( travel_benefits = travel_data, employment_base = employment_data, multipliers = implan_multipliers ) # 3. Spatial Distribution impact_map <- map_economic_effects(economic_impacts, study_area) ``` ::: {.notes} - Have this ready if they want to dig into technical implementation - Shows actual R code skills and modern workflow practices - Demonstrates understanding of reproducible research principles ::: --- ### Additional Case Studies **Other Projects Demonstrating Methodology:** - **Bowling Green-Warren County MPO (KY)**: $180M transportation plan economic analysis - **Lower Savannah COG (SC)**: Multi-county freight corridor impact assessment - **Des Moines Area MPO**: Transit investment economic evaluation - **Ohio DOT Cleveland**: Intersection improvement benefit-cost analysis **Consistent Approach**: Integration of travel demand modeling outputs with regional economic impact models using automated R workflows ::: {.notes} - Shows breadth of experience across different regions and project types - Demonstrates that the methodology is transferable and scalable - All used similar R-based integration approaches :::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
